This action is irreversible!
confirm.unlink_sources:
Remove symbolic link for kernel {version} from /usr/src/?

This will only remove the link, not the sources.

drivers.warning_official_install:
You are about to install a driver from the official website.

This is an advanced operation that may:
‚Ä¢ Require a reboot in console mode
‚Ä¢ Cause stability issues
‚Ä¢ Complicate future updates

Installation from repositories is recommended for most users.

Do you really want to continue?
drivers.warning_nvidia_run:
‚ö†Ô∏è NVIDIA: Installation may require stopping the graphical server.
Your session might be interrupted.
drivers.warning_nvidia_intelligent:
ü§ñ NVIDIA Smart Installation

The system will automatically detect your graphics environment and choose the best installation method.

If you're using X11 or Wayland, a systemd service will be created to install the driver on next reboot.
drivers.opensource_fallback: The system will use the open source driver after reboot.
drivers.backup_saved: Backup successfully saved in drivers_backup folder
drivers.backup_recommended:
It is recommended to create a backup of the current driver before installing a new one.

This will allow you to roll back if there are issues.

drivers.intel_no_removal:
Intel drivers are integrated into the kernel and cannot be removed.

Intel uses open source drivers (i915/xe) provided by the Linux kernel.

Restore backup {backup_id}?

secureboot.install_dependencies_confirm: Do you want to install the missing dependencies?
secureboot.instructions_text:
SecureBoot is a UEFI security feature that prevents loading unsigned code at boot.

‚Ä¢ To ENABLE SecureBoot: Reboot and access BIOS/UEFI (F2/F10/Del), then enable SecureBoot in security settings.

‚Ä¢ To DISABLE SecureBoot: Same procedure, disable SecureBoot in BIOS/UEFI.

‚Ä¢ To use custom kernels with SecureBoot enabled, you must sign kernel modules with your own MOK (Machine Owner Keys).
secureboot.no_enrolled_keys: No MOK keys are enrolled on this system.
secureboot.keys_warning: WARNING: Modifying MOK keys requires a reboot and confirmation at boot (MOK Manager).
secureboot.import_key_details:
After import, you will need to:
1. Reboot the system
2. At boot, MOK Manager will open
3. Select 'Enroll MOK'
4. Enter the password you will define
5. Reboot again

Do you want to continue?
secureboot.reset_keys_warning:
WARNING: This action will remove all enrolled MOK keys.

You will need to reboot and confirm in MOK Manager.

Do you really want to continue?
secureboot.no_terminal: No compatible terminal found to execute the command.
secureboot.generate_key_now:
Do you want to generate a new signing key now?

This will allow automatic signing of kernel modules.
secureboot.sign_modules_now: Do you want to sign the kernel modules now?
secureboot.select_signing_key: Select the key to use for signing:
secureboot.please_wait: Please wait, this may take a few minutes.
secureboot.modules_signed_partial:
Partial signing: {signed}/{total} modules signed.

{failed} modules failed.
secureboot.enrollment_explanation: This operation will import your MOK key. Here's what will happen:
secureboot.create_temp_password: You will create a temporary password (8-16 characters)
secureboot.mok_manager_screen: At reboot, a blue 'MOK Manager' screen will appear:
secureboot.enter_password: Enter the password you will create
secureboot.key_enrolled_success: Your key will be enrolled and your custom kernels will be able to boot!
secureboot.password_length_error: Password must be between 8 and 16 characters
secureboot.follow_mok_manager_instructions: Follow MOK Manager instructions at reboot.
secureboot.reboot_now_question: Do you want to reboot now?
secureboot.reboot_confirm_message:
Are you sure you want to reboot now?

Make sure you have saved all your work.
secureboot.also_sign_vmlinuz: Also sign vmlinuz images (recommended for SecureBoot)
